column4: what's the equivalent of cat /proc/acpi/thermal_zone/THRM/temperature on ubuntu?
that line works on my computer.. it doesn't on yours?
nah
hmm.. I've installed some sensor stuff.. lm-sensors might be a good start.. I don't know if that puts stuff in the /proc tree though
alright
here's some old info (they mention dapper which is.. well. old =) http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=385446
have you google for the error message?
of course, they all say what LordC said
I don't think a group can own a file
directory even?
it has to be user and group... but you can set permissions for the group
nope, not even for a idrectory
are you using command line?
chmod g+rw filename  will make everyone in the group have read and write permissions
the 'g' means the change the permissions for the group, +r means to add read permissions, +w means to add write permissions.. +r+w is written as +rw
not if the file is alread owned by a user and a group
what you write in the chmod command will be for the group that owns the file
you can change what group owns the file later and the permissions will transfer.. the file only knows that "my group can read/write me", not that "group gr1 can read/write me"
that looks right
one last question, if a user within the group creates a file in that dir, somedir/, it will still be the same permissions right? meaning the group will have ownership, since I did it recursively
if you're going to be using special permissions with lots of weird users/groups there are stuff you can install to let you use acl's.. I think it's pretty much like in windows
hmm.. there is a setting for that too.. if new files in a folder inherites the parent folders permissions.. not sure how to set it though.. might be something called guid but I'm not sure
you're welcome
